To skip unnecessary wake-up initialize a timer with the "skip_unhandled_events" option as true.

If disabled, automatic light sleep support will be disabled.
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_TICKLESS_IDLE
children.title: Tickless idle support

children.help:
If enabled, all FreeRTOS task functions will be enclosed in a wrapper function.
If a task function mistakenly returns (i.e. does not delete), the call flow will
return to the wrapper function. The wrapper function will then log an error and
abort the application. This option is also required for GDB backtraces and C++
exceptions to work correctly inside top-level task functions.
children.name: FREERTOS_TASK_FUNCTION_WRAPPER
children.title: Enclose all task functions in a wrapper function

children.help:
If enabled, assert that when a mutex semaphore is given, the task giving the
semaphore is the task which is currently holding the mutex.
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_MUTEX_GIVEN_BY_OWNER
children.title: Check that mutex semaphore is given by owner task

children.help:
If enabled, context of port*_CRITICAL calls (ISR or Non-ISR)
would be checked to be in compliance with Vanilla FreeRTOS.
e.g Calling port*_CRITICAL from ISR context would cause assert failure
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_PORT_CRITICAL_COMPLIANCE
children.title: Tests compliance with Vanilla FreeRTOS port*_CRITICAL calls

children.help:
When enabled the selected Non-ISR FreeRTOS functions will be placed into Flash memory instead of IRAM.
This saves up to 8KB of IRAM depending on which functions are used.
children.name: FREERTOS_PLACE_FUNCTIONS_INTO_FLASH
children.title: Place FreeRTOS functions into Flash

children.help: Hidden option, gets selected by CONFIG_ESPxx_DEBUG_OCDAWARE
children.name: FREERTOS_DEBUG_OCDAWARE

children.help:
When enabled, the usage of float type is allowed inside Level 1
ISRs.
children.name: FREERTOS_FPU_IN_ISR
children.title: Allow use of float inside Level 1 ISR (EXPERIMENTAL)

children.help:
When enabled, the functions related to snapshots, such as vTaskGetSnapshot or uxTaskGetSnapshotAll,
will be placed in flash. Note that if enabled, these functions cannot be called when cache is disabled.
children.name: FREERTOS_PLACE_SNAPSHOT_FUNS_INTO_FLASH
children.title: Place task snapshot functions into flash

children.help:
When enabled, the functions related to snapshots, such as vTaskGetSnapshot or uxTaskGetSnapshotAll,
are compiled and linked.
children.name: FREERTOS_ENABLE_TASK_SNAPSHOT
children.title: Enable task snapshot functions

children.help:
Set the assert behavior / level for HAL component.
HAL component assert level can be set separately,
but the level can't exceed the system assertion level.
e.g. If the system assertion is disabled, then the HAL
assertion can't be enabled either. If the system assertion
is enable, then the HAL assertion can still be disabled
by this Kconfig option.
children.name: HAL_DEFAULT_ASSERTION_LEVEL
children.title: Default HAL assertion level
Hardware Abstraction Layer (HAL) and Low Level (LL)

children.help:
Enable heap poisoning features to detect heap corruption caused by out-of-bounds access to heap memory.

See the "Heap Memory Debugging" page of the IDF documentation
for a description of each level of heap corruption detection.
children.name: HEAP_CORRUPTION_DETECTION
children.title: Heap corruption detection

children.help:
Enables the heap tracing API defined in esp_heap_trace.h.

This function causes a moderate increase in IRAM code side and a minor increase in heap function
(malloc/free/realloc) CPU overhead, even when the tracing feature is not used.
So it's best to keep it disabled unless tracing is being used.
children.name: HEAP_TRACING_DEST
children.title: Heap tracing

children.help: Enables/disables heap tracing API.
children.name: HEAP_TRACING

children.help:
Number of stack frames to save when tracing heap operation callers.

More stack frames uses more memory in the heap trace buffer (and slows down allocation), but
can provide useful information.
children.name: HEAP_TRACING_STACK_DEPTH
children.title: Heap tracing stack depth

children.help:
Enables tracking the task responsible for each heap allocation.

This function depends on heap poisoning being enabled and adds four more bytes of overhead for each block
allocated.
children.name: HEAP_TASK_TRACKING
children.title: Enable heap task tracking

children.help: When enabled, if a memory allocation operation fails it will cause a system abort.
children.name: HEAP_ABORT_WHEN_ALLOCATION_FAILS
children.title: Abort if memory allocation fails

children.help: Override the shipped lib802154.a for internal builds.
children.name: IEEE802154_LIB_FROM_INTERNAL_SRC
children.title: Build IEEE 802.15.4 libraries from source

children.help: You can access to parent node of parsed json
children.name: JSMN_PARENT_LINKS
children.title: Enable parent links

children.help: In strict mode primitives are: numbers and booleans
children.name: JSMN_STRICT
children.title: Enable strict mode

children.help:
If this option is enabled, libsodium will use thin wrappers
around mbedTLS for SHA256 & SHA512 operations.

This saves some code size if mbedTLS is also used. However it
is incompatible with hardware SHA acceleration (due to the
way libsodium's API manages SHA state).
children.name: LIBSODIUM_USE_MBEDTLS_SHA
children.title: Use mbedTLS SHA256 & SHA512 implementations

children.help:
Specify how much output to see in logs by default.
You can set lower verbosity level at runtime using
esp_log_level_set function.

By default, this setting limits which log statements
are compiled into the program. For example, selecting
"Warning" would mean that changing log level to "Debug"
at runtime will not be possible. To allow increasing log
level above the default at runtime, see the next option.
children.name: LOG_DEFAULT_LEVEL
children.title: Default log verbosity

children.help:
This config option sets the highest log verbosity that it's possible to select
at runtime by calling esp_log_level_set(). This level may be higher than
the default verbosity level which is set when the app starts up.

This can be used enable debugging output only at a critical point, for a particular
tag, or to minimize startup time but then enable more logs once the firmware has
loaded.

Note that increasing the maximum available log level will increase the firmware
binary size.

This option only applies to logging from the app, the bootloader log level is
fixed at compile time to the separate "Bootloader log verbosity" setting.
children.name: LOG_MAXIMUM_LEVEL
children.title: Maximum log verbosity

children.help:
Enable ANSI terminal color codes in bootloader output.

In order to view these, your terminal program must support ANSI color codes.
children.name: LOG_COLORS
children.title: Use ANSI terminal colors in log output

children.help:
Choose what sort of timestamp is displayed in the log output:

- Milliseconds since boot is calulated from the RTOS tick count multiplied
  by the tick period. This time will reset after a software reboot.
  e.g. (90000)

- System time is taken from POSIX time functions which use the ESP32's
  RTC and FRC1 timers to maintain an accurate time. The system time is
  initialized to 0 on startup, it can be set with an SNTP sync, or with
  POSIX time functions. This time will not reset after a software reboot.
  e.g. (00:01:30.000)

- NOTE: Currently this will not get used in logging from binary blobs
  (i.e WiFi & Bluetooth libraries), these will always print
  milliseconds since boot.
children.name: LOG_TIMESTAMP_SOURCE
children.title: Log Timestamps

children.help:
The default name this device will report to other devices on the network.
Could be updated at runtime with esp_netif_set_hostname()
children.name: LWIP_LOCAL_HOSTNAME
children.title: Local netif hostname

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, standard POSIX APIs: if_indextoname(), if_nametoindex()
could be used to convert network interface index to name
instead of IDF specific esp-netif APIs (such as esp_netif_get_netif_impl_name())
children.name: LWIP_NETIF_API
children.title: Enable usage of standard POSIX APIs in LWIP

children.help:
If Enable tcpip　core locking,Creates a global mutex that is held
during TCPIP thread operations.Can be locked by client code to perform
lwIP operations without changing into TCPIP thread using callbacks.
See LOCK_TCPIP_CORE() and UNLOCK_TCPIP_CORE().

If disable tcpip　core locking,TCP IP will perform tasks through context switching．
children.name: LWIP_TCPIP_CORE_LOCKING
children.title: Enable tcpip　core locking

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, standard API such as gethostbyname
support .local addresses by sending one shot multicast mDNS
query
children.name: LWIP_DNS_SUPPORT_MDNS_QUERIES
children.title: Enable mDNS queries in resolving host name

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, all traffic from layer2(WIFI Driver) will be
copied to a new buffer before sending it to layer3(LWIP stack), freeing
the layer2 buffer.
Please be notified that the total layer2 receiving buffer is fixed and
ESP32 currently supports 25 layer2 receiving buffer, when layer2 buffer
runs out of memory, then the incoming packets will be dropped in hardware.
The layer3 buffer is allocated from the heap, so the total layer3 receiving
buffer depends on the available heap size, when heap runs out of memory,
no copy will be sent to layer3 and packet will be dropped in layer2.
Please make sure you fully understand the impact of this feature before
enabling it.
children.name: LWIP_L2_TO_L3_COPY
children.title: Enable copy between Layer2 and Layer3 packets

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, some functions relating to RX/TX in LWIP will be
put into IRAM, it can improve UDP/TCP throughput by >10% for single core mode,
it doesn't help too much for dual core mode. On the other hand, it needs about
10KB IRAM for these optimizations.

If this feature is disabled, all lwip functions will be put into FLASH.
children.name: LWIP_IRAM_OPTIMIZATION
children.title: Enable LWIP IRAM optimization

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, IGMP and MLD6 timers will be activated only
when joining groups or receiving QUERY packets.

This feature will reduce the power consumption for applications which do not
use IGMP and MLD6.
children.name: LWIP_TIMERS_ONDEMAND
children.title: Enable LWIP Timers on demand

children.help:
Sockets take up a certain amount of memory, and allowing fewer
sockets to be open at the same time conserves memory. Specify
the maximum amount of sockets here. The valid value is from 1
to 16.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_SOCKETS
children.title: Max number of open sockets

children.help:
This option is deprecated. Use VFS_SUPPORT_SELECT instead, which is
the inverse of this option.

The virtual filesystem layer of select() redirects sockets to
lwip_select() and non-socket file descriptors to their respective driver
implementations. If this option is enabled then all calls of select()
will be redirected to lwip_select(), therefore, select can be used
for sockets only.
children.name: LWIP_USE_ONLY_LWIP_SELECT
children.title: Support LWIP socket select() only (DEPRECATED)

children.help:
Enabling this option allows SO_LINGER processing.
l_onoff = 1,l_linger can set the timeout.

If l_linger=0, When a connection is closed, TCP will terminate the connection.
This means that TCP will discard any data packets stored in the socket send buffer
and send an RST to the peer.

If l_linger!=0,Then closesocket() calls to block the process until
the remaining data packets has been sent or timed out.
children.name: LWIP_SO_LINGER
children.title: Enable SO_LINGER processing

children.help:
Enabling this option means that any incoming broadcast or multicast
packet will be copied to all of the local sockets that it matches
(may be more than one if SO_REUSEADDR is set on the socket.)

This increases memory overhead as the packets need to be copied,
however they are only copied per matching socket. You can safely
disable it if you don't plan to receive broadcast or multicast
traffic on more than one socket at a time.
children.name: LWIP_SO_REUSE_RXTOALL
children.title: SO_REUSEADDR copies broadcast/multicast to all matches

children.help:
Enabling this option allows binding to a port which remains in
TIME_WAIT.
children.name: LWIP_SO_REUSE
children.title: Enable SO_REUSEADDR option

children.help: Enabling this option allows checking for available data on a netconn.
children.name: LWIP_SO_RCVBUF
children.title: Enable SO_RCVBUF option

children.help:
Enabling this option allows checking for the destination address
of a received IPv4 Packet.
children.name: LWIP_NETBUF_RECVINFO
children.title: Enable IP_PKTINFO option

children.help:
Enabling this option allows fragmenting outgoing IP4 packets if their size
exceeds MTU.
children.name: LWIP_IP4_FRAG
children.title: Enable fragment outgoing IP4 packets

children.help:
Enabling this option allows fragmenting outgoing IP6 packets if their size
exceeds MTU.
children.name: LWIP_IP6_FRAG
children.title: Enable fragment outgoing IP6 packets

children.help: Enabling this option allows reassemblying incoming fragmented IP4 packets.
children.name: LWIP_IP4_REASSEMBLY
children.title: Enable reassembly incoming fragmented IP4 packets

children.help: Enabling this option allows reassemblying incoming fragmented IP6 packets.
children.name: LWIP_IP6_REASSEMBLY
children.title: Enable reassembly incoming fragmented IP6 packets

children.help: Enabling this option allows Network Address and Port Translation.
children.name: LWIP_IPV4_NAPT
children.title: Enable NAT (new/experimental)

children.help: Enabling this option allows packets forwarding across multiple interfaces.
children.name: LWIP_IP_FORWARD
children.title: Enable IP forwarding

children.help: Enabling this option allows LWIP statistics
children.name: LWIP_STATS
children.title: Enable LWIP statistics

children.help:
Enabling this option allows ARP table to be updated.

If this option is enabled, the incoming IP packets cause the ARP table to be
updated with the source MAC and IP addresses supplied in the packet.
You may want to disable this if you do not trust LAN peers to have the
correct addresses, or as a limited approach to attempt to handle
spoofing. If disabled, lwIP will need to make a new ARP request if
the peer is not already in the ARP table, adding a little latency.
The peer *is* in the ARP table if it requested our address before.
Also notice that this slows down input processing of every IP packet!

There are two known issues in real application if this feature is enabled:
- The LAN peer may have bug to update the ARP table after the ARP entry is aged out.
If the ARP entry on the LAN peer is aged out but failed to be updated, all IP packets
sent from LWIP to the LAN peer will be dropped by LAN peer.
- The LAN peer may not be trustful, the LAN peer may send IP packets to LWIP with
two different MACs, but the same IP address. If this happens, the LWIP has problem
to receive IP packets from LAN peer.

So the recommendation is to disable this option.
Here the LAN peer means the other side to which the ESP station or soft-AP is connected.
children.name: LWIP_ETHARP_TRUST_IP_MAC
children.title: Enable LWIP ARP trust

children.help: Set the timer interval for gratuitous ARP. The default value is 60s
children.name: LWIP_GARP_TMR_INTERVAL
children.title: GARP timer interval(seconds)

children.help:
Enable this option allows to send gratuitous ARP periodically.

This option solve the compatibility issues.If the ARP table of the AP is old, and the AP
doesn't send ARP request to update it's ARP table, this will lead to the STA sending IP packet fail.
Thus we send gratuitous ARP periodically to let AP update it's ARP table.
children.name: LWIP_ESP_GRATUITOUS_ARP
children.title: Send gratuitous ARP periodically

children.help:
Set TCPIP task receive mail box size. Generally bigger value means higher throughput
but more memory. The value should be bigger than UDP/TCP mail box size.
children.name: LWIP_TCPIP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: TCPIP task receive mail box size

children.help:
Enabling this option performs a check (via ARP request) if the offered IP address
is not already in use by another host on the network.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_DOES_ARP_CHECK
children.title: DHCP: Perform ARP check on any offered address

children.help:
This option could be used to disable DHCP client identification with its MAC address.
(Client id is used by DHCP servers to uniquely identify clients and are included
in the DHCP packets as an option 61)
Set this option to "y" in order to exclude option 61 from DHCP packets.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_DISABLE_CLIENT_ID
children.title: DHCP: Disable Use of HW address as client identification

children.help:
This option could be used to disable DHCP client vendor class identification.
Set this option to "y" in order to exclude option 60 from DHCP packets.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_DISABLE_VENDOR_CLASS_ID
children.title: DHCP: Disable Use of vendor class identification

children.help:
When this option is enabled, DHCP client tries to re-obtain last valid IP address obtained from DHCP
server. Last valid DHCP configuration is stored in nvs and restored after reset/power-up. If IP is still
available, there is no need for sending discovery message to DHCP server and save some time.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_RESTORE_LAST_IP
children.title: DHCP: Restore last IP obtained from DHCP server

children.help:
Set total length of outgoing DHCP option msg. Generally bigger value means it can carry more
options and values. If your code meets LWIP_ASSERT due to option value is too long.
Please increase the LWIP_DHCP_OPTIONS_LEN value.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_OPTIONS_LEN
children.title: DHCP total option length

children.help:
The DHCP server is calculating lease time multiplying the sent
and received times by this number of seconds per unit.
The default is 60, that equals one minute.
children.name: LWIP_DHCPS_LEASE_UNIT
children.title: Multiplier for lease time, in seconds

children.help:
The maximum number of DHCP clients that are connected to the server.
After this number is exceeded, DHCP server removes of the oldest device
from it's address pool, without notification.
children.name: LWIP_DHCPS_MAX_STATION_NUM
children.title: Maximum number of stations

children.help:
Enabling this option allows the device to run the DHCP server
(to dynamically assign IPv4 addresses to clients).
children.name: LWIP_DHCPS
children.title: DHCPS: Enable IPv4 Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol Server (DHCPS)

children.help:
DHCP client will send this many probes before self-assigning a
link local address.

From LWIP help: "This can be set as low as 1 to get an AutoIP
address very quickly, but you should be prepared to handle a
changing IP address when DHCP overrides AutoIP." (In the case of
ESP-IDF, this means multiple SYSTEM_EVENT_STA_GOT_IP events.)
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP_TRIES
children.title: DHCP Probes before self-assigning IPv4 LL address

children.help:
If the AUTOIP functionality detects this many IP conflicts while
self-assigning an address, it will go into a rate limited mode.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP_MAX_CONFLICTS
children.title: Max IP conflicts before rate limiting

children.help:
If rate limiting self-assignment requests, wait this long between
each request.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP_RATE_LIMIT_INTERVAL
children.title: Rate limited interval (seconds)

children.help:
Enabling this option allows the device to self-assign an address
in the 169.256/16 range if none is assigned statically or via DHCP.

See RFC 3927.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP
children.title: Enable IPV4 Link-Local Addressing (AUTOIP)

children.help:
Enabling this option allows the devices to IPV6 stateless address autoconfiguration (SLAAC).

See RFC 4862.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_AUTOCONFIG
children.title: Enable IPV6 stateless address autoconfiguration (SLAAC)

children.help:
The maximum number of IPv6 addresses on each interface. Any additional
addresses will be discarded.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_NUM_ADDRESSES
children.title: Number of IPv6 addresses on each network interface

children.help:
Forwarding IPv6 packets between interfaces is only required when acting as
a router.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_FORWARD
children.title: Enable IPv6 forwarding between interfaces

children.help:
Enable IPv6 function. If not use IPv6 function, set this option to n.
If disabling LWIP_IPV6 then some other components (coap and asio) will
no longer be available.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6
children.title: Enable IPv6

children.help:
Use IPv6 Router Advertisement Recursive DNS Server Option (as per RFC 6106) to
copy a defined maximum number of DNS servers to the DNS module.
Set this option to a number of desired DNS servers advertised in the RA protocol.
This feature is disabled when set to 0.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_RDNSS_MAX_DNS_SERVERS
children.title: Use IPv6 Router Advertisement Recursive DNS Server Option

children.name: LWIP_IPV6_DHCP6
children.title: Enable DHCPv6 stateless address autoconfiguration

children.help: Enable callbacks when the network interface is up/down and addresses are changed.
children.name: LWIP_NETIF_STATUS_CALLBACK
children.title: Enable status callback for network interfaces

children.help:
Configure the maximum number of packets which can be queued for
loopback on a given interface. Reducing this number may cause packets
to be dropped, but will avoid filling memory with queued packet data.
children.name: LWIP_LOOPBACK_MAX_PBUFS
children.title: Max queued loopback packets per interface

children.help:
Enabling this option means that if a packet is sent with a destination
address equal to the interface's own IP address, it will "loop back" and
be received by this interface.
children.name: LWIP_NETIF_LOOPBACK
children.title: Support per-interface loopback

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously active TCP
connections. The practical maximum limit is
determined by available heap memory at runtime.

Changing this value by itself does not substantially
change the memory usage of LWIP, except for preventing
new TCP connections after the limit is reached.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_ACTIVE_TCP
children.title: Maximum active TCP Connections

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously listening TCP
connections. The practical maximum limit is
determined by available heap memory at runtime.

Changing this value by itself does not substantially
change the memory usage of LWIP, except for preventing
new listening TCP connections after the limit is reached.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_LISTENING_TCP
children.title: Maximum listening TCP Connections

children.help:
Speed up the TCP retransmission interval. If disabled,
it is recommended to change the number of SYN retransmissions to 6,
and TCP initial rto time to 3000.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_HIGH_SPEED_RETRANSMISSION
children.title: TCP high speed retransmissions

children.help: Set maximum number of retransmissions of data segments.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_MAXRTX
children.title: Maximum number of retransmissions of data segments

children.help: Set maximum number of retransmissions of SYN segments.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_SYNMAXRTX
children.title: Maximum number of retransmissions of SYN segments

children.help:
Set maximum segment size for TCP transmission.

Can be set lower to save RAM, the default value 1460(ipv4)/1440(ipv6) will give best throughput.
IPv4 TCP_MSS Range: 576 <= TCP_MSS <= 1460
IPv6 TCP_MSS Range: 1220<= TCP_mSS <= 1440
children.name: LWIP_TCP_MSS
children.title: Maximum Segment Size (MSS)

children.help:
Set TCP timer interval in milliseconds.

Can be used to speed connections on bad networks.
A lower value will redeliver unacked packets faster.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_TMR_INTERVAL
children.title: TCP timer interval(ms)

children.help: Set maximum segment lifetime in in milliseconds.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_MSL
children.title: Maximum segment lifetime (MSL)

children.help:
Set default send buffer size for new TCP sockets.

Per-socket send buffer size can be changed at runtime
with lwip_setsockopt(s, TCP_SNDBUF, ...).

This value must be at least 2x the MSS size, and the default
is 4x the default MSS size.

Setting a smaller default SNDBUF size can save some RAM, but
will decrease performance.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_SND_BUF_DEFAULT
children.title: Default send buffer size

children.help:
Set default TCP receive window size for new TCP sockets.

Per-socket receive window size can be changed at runtime
with lwip_setsockopt(s, TCP_WINDOW, ...).

Setting a smaller default receive window size can save some RAM,
but will significantly decrease performance.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_WND_DEFAULT
children.title: Default receive window size

children.help:
Set TCP receive mail box size. Generally bigger value means higher throughput
but more memory. The recommended value is: LWIP_TCP_WND_DEFAULT/TCP_MSS + 2, e.g. if
LWIP_TCP_WND_DEFAULT=14360, TCP_MSS=1436, then the recommended receive mail box size is
(14360/1436 + 2) = 12.

TCP receive mail box is a per socket mail box, when the application receives packets
from TCP socket, LWIP core firstly posts the packets to TCP receive mail box and the
application then fetches the packets from mail box. It means LWIP can caches maximum
LWIP_TCP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE packets for each TCP socket, so the maximum possible cached TCP packets
for all TCP sockets is LWIP_TCP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE multiples the maximum TCP socket number. In other
words, the bigger LWIP_TCP_RECVMBOX_SIZE means more memory.
On the other hand, if the receiv mail box is too small, the mail box may be full. If the
mail box is full, the LWIP drops the packets. So generally we need to make sure the TCP
receive mail box is big enough to avoid packet drop between LWIP core and application.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: Default TCP receive mail box size

children.help:
Queue incoming out-of-order segments for later use.

Disable this option to save some RAM during TCP sessions, at the expense
of increased retransmissions if segments arrive out of order.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_QUEUE_OOSEQ
children.title: Queue incoming out-of-order segments

children.help: TCP will support sending selective acknowledgements (SACKs).
children.name: LWIP_TCP_SACK_OUT
children.title: Support sending selective acknowledgements

children.help:
This option is enabled when the following scenario happen:
network dropped and reconnected, IP changes is like: 192.168.0.2->0.0.0.0->192.168.0.2

Disable this option to keep consistent with the original LWIP code behavior.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_KEEP_CONNECTION_WHEN_IP_CHANGES
children.title: Keep TCP connections when IP changed

children.help:
Allows enabling "oversize" allocation of TCP transmission pbufs ahead of time,
which can reduce the length of pbuf chains used for transmission.

This will not make a difference to sockets where Nagle's algorithm
is disabled.

Default value of MSS is fine for most applications, 25% MSS may save
some RAM when only transmitting small amounts of data. Disabled will
have worst performance and fragmentation characteristics, but uses
least RAM overall.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_OVERSIZE
children.title: Pre-allocate transmit PBUF size

children.help: Enable this feature to support TCP window scaling.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_RCV_SCALE
children.title: Set TCP receiving window scaling factor

children.help: Enable this feature to support TCP window scaling.
children.name: LWIP_WND_SCALE
children.title: Support TCP window scale

children.help:
Set default TCP rto time for a reasonable initial rto.
In bad network environment, recommend set value of rto time to 1500.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_RTO_TIME
children.title: Default TCP rto time

children.help:
The maximum number of active UDP "connections" (ie
UDP sockets sending/receiving data).
The practical maximum limit is determined by available
heap memory at runtime.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_UDP_PCBS
children.title: Maximum active UDP control blocks

children.help:
Set UDP receive mail box size. The recommended value is 6.

UDP receive mail box is a per socket mail box, when the application receives packets
from UDP socket, LWIP core firstly posts the packets to UDP receive mail box and the
application then fetches the packets from mail box. It means LWIP can caches maximum
UDP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE packets for each UDP socket, so the maximum possible cached UDP packets
for all UDP sockets is UDP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE multiples the maximum UDP socket number. In other
words, the bigger UDP_RECVMBOX_SIZE means more memory.
On the other hand, if the receiv mail box is too small, the mail box may be full. If the
mail box is full, the LWIP drops the packets. So generally we need to make sure the UDP
receive mail box is big enough to avoid packet drop between LWIP core and application.
children.name: LWIP_UDP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: Default UDP receive mail box size

children.help: Enable checksum checking for received IP messages
children.name: LWIP_CHECKSUM_CHECK_IP
children.title: Enable LWIP IP checksums

children.help: Enable checksum checking for received UDP messages
children.name: LWIP_CHECKSUM_CHECK_UDP
children.title: Enable LWIP UDP checksums

children.help: Enable checksum checking for received ICMP messages
children.name: LWIP_CHECKSUM_CHECK_ICMP
children.title: Enable LWIP ICMP checksums

children.help:
Configure TCP/IP task stack size, used by LWIP to process multi-threaded TCP/IP operations.
Setting this stack too small will result in stack overflow crashes.
children.name: LWIP_TCPIP_TASK_STACK_SIZE
children.title: TCP/IP Task Stack Size

children.help:
Allows setting LwIP tasks affinity, i.e. whether the task is pinned to
CPU0, pinned to CPU1, or allowed to run on any CPU.
Currently this applies to "TCP/IP" task and "Ping" task.
children.name: LWIP_TCPIP_TASK_AFFINITY
children.title: TCP/IP task affinity

children.help:
Enable IPV6 support in PPP for the local link between the DTE (processor) and DCE (modem).
There are some modems which do not support the IPV6 addressing in the local link.
If they are requested for IPV6CP negotiation, they may time out.
This would in turn fail the configuration for the whole link.
If your modem is not responding correctly to PPP Phase Network, try to disable IPV6 support.
children.name: LWIP_PPP_ENABLE_IPV6
children.title: Enable IPV6 support for PPP connections (IPV6CP)

children.help:
Enable PPP stack. Now only PPP over serial is possible.

PPP over serial support is experimental and unsupported.
children.name: LWIP_PPP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable PPP support (new/experimental)

children.help: Config max number of IPv6 packets to queue during MAC resolution.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_MEMP_NUM_ND6_QUEUE
children.title: Max number of IPv6 packets to queue during MAC resolution

children.help: Config max number of entries in IPv6 neighbor cache
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_ND6_NUM_NEIGHBORS
children.title: Max number of entries in IPv6 neighbor cache

children.help: Enable to set a callback which is called on change of the internal PPP state machine.
children.name: LWIP_PPP_NOTIFY_PHASE_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable Notify Phase Callback

children.help: Enable Password Authentication Protocol (PAP) support
children.name: LWIP_PPP_PAP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable PAP support

children.help: Enable Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol (CHAP) support
children.name: LWIP_PPP_CHAP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable CHAP support

children.help: Enable Microsoft version of the Challenge-Handshake Authentication Protocol (MSCHAP) support
children.name: LWIP_PPP_MSCHAP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable MSCHAP support

children.help: Enable Microsoft Point-to-Point Encryption (MPPE) support
children.name: LWIP_PPP_MPPE_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable MPPE support

children.help: Interval in seconds between keepalive LCP echo requests, 0 to disable.
children.name: LWIP_LCP_ECHOINTERVAL
children.title: Echo interval (s)

children.help: Number of consecutive unanswered echo requests before failure is indicated.
children.name: LWIP_LCP_MAXECHOFAILS
children.title: Maximum echo failures

children.help: Enable LCP echo keepalive requests
children.name: LWIP_ENABLE_LCP_ECHO
children.title: Enable LCP ECHO

children.help: Enable PPP debug log output
children.name: LWIP_PPP_DEBUG_ON
children.title: Enable PPP debug log output

children.help: Enable SLIP debug log output
children.name: LWIP_SLIP_DEBUG_ON
children.title: Enable SLIP debug log output

children.help:
Enable SLIP stack. Now only SLIP over serial is possible.

SLIP over serial support is experimental and unsupported.
children.name: LWIP_SLIP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable SLIP support (new/experimental)

children.help: Enable ICMP module for check network stability
children.name: LWIP_ICMP
children.title: ICMP: Enable ICMP

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously active LWIP
RAW protocol control blocks. The practical maximum
limit is determined by available heap memory at runtime.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_RAW_PCBS
children.title: Maximum LWIP RAW PCBs

children.help:
Set maximum number of NTP servers used by LwIP SNTP module.
First argument of sntp_setserver/sntp_setservername functions
is limited to this value.
children.name: LWIP_SNTP_MAX_SERVERS
children.title: Maximum number of NTP servers

children.help:
Set maximum number of NTP servers aquired via DHCP-offer.
Should be less or equal to "Maximum number of NTP servers", any extra servers would be just ignored.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_MAX_NTP_SERVERS
children.title: Maximum number of NTP servers aquired via DHCP

children.help:
If enabled, LWIP will add 'NTP' to Parameter-Request Option sent via DHCP-request.
DHCP server might reply with an NTP server address in option 42.
SNTP callback for such replies should be set accordingly (see sntp_servermode_dhcp() func.)
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_GET_NTP_SRV
children.title: Request NTP servers from DHCP

children.help:
This option allows you to set the time update period via SNTP.
Default is 1 hour. Must not be below 15 seconds by specification.
(SNTPv4 RFC 4330 enforces a minimum update time of 15 seconds).
children.name: LWIP_SNTP_UPDATE_DELAY
children.title: Request interval to update time (ms)

children.help:
Enable this option keeps LWIP assertion checks enabled.
It is recommended to keep this option enabled.

If asserts are disabled for the entire project, they are also disabled
for LWIP and this option is ignored.
children.name: LWIP_ESP_LWIP_ASSERT
children.title: Enable LWIP ASSERT checks

children.help:
Enables to define a TCP ISN hook to randomize initial sequence
number in TCP connection.
The default TCP ISN algorithm used in IDF (standardized in RFC 6528)
produces ISN by combining an MD5 of the new TCP id and a stable
secret with the current time.
This is because the lwIP implementation (`tcp_next_iss`) is not
very strong, as it does not take into consideration any platform
specific entropy source.

Set to LWIP_HOOK_TCP_ISN_CUSTOM to provide custom implementation.
Set to LWIP_HOOK_TCP_ISN_NONE to use lwIP implementation.
children.name: LWIP_HOOK_TCP_ISN
children.title: TCP ISN Hook

children.help:
Enables custom IPv6 route hook.
Setting this to "default" provides weak implementation
stub that could be overwritten in application code.
Setting this to "custom" provides hook's declaration
only and expects the application to implement it.
children.name: LWIP_HOOK_IP6_ROUTE
children.title: IPv6 route Hook

children.help:
Enables custom IPv6 route hook.
Setting this to "default" provides weak implementation
stub that could be overwritten in application code.
Setting this to "custom" provides hook's declaration
only and expects the application to implement it.
children.name: LWIP_HOOK_ND6_GET_GW
children.title: IPv6 get gateway Hook

children.help:
Enables custom DNS resolve hook.
Setting this to "default" provides weak implementation
stub that could be overwritten in application code.
Setting this to "custom" provides hook's declaration
only and expects the application to implement it.
children.name: LWIP_HOOK_NETCONN_EXTERNAL_RESOLVE
children.title: Netconn external resolve Hook

children.help:
Enabling this option allows different kinds of lwIP debug output.

All lwIP debug features increase the size of the final binary.
children.name: LWIP_DEBUG
children.title: Enable LWIP Debug

children.help:
Allows to use IRAM memory region as 8bit accessible region.

TLS input and output buffers will be allocated in IRAM section which is 32bit aligned
memory. Every unaligned (8bit or 16bit) access will result in an exception
and incur penalty of certain clock cycles per unaligned read/write.
children.name: MBEDTLS_IRAM_8BIT_MEM_ALLOC
children.title: Internal IRAM

children.help:
Allocation strategy for mbedTLS, essentially provides ability to
allocate all required dynamic allocations from,

- Internal DRAM memory only
- External SPIRAM memory only
- Either internal or external memory based on default malloc()
  behavior in ESP-IDF
- Custom allocation mode, by overwriting calloc()/free() using
  mbedtls_platform_set_calloc_free() function
- Internal IRAM memory wherever applicable else internal DRAM

Recommended mode here is always internal (*), since that is most preferred
from security perspective. But if application requirement does not
allow sufficient free internal memory then alternate mode can be
selected.

(*) In case of ESP32-S2/ESP32-S3, hardware allows encryption of external
SPIRAM contents provided hardware flash encryption feature is enabled.
In that case, using external SPIRAM allocation strategy is also safe choice
from security perspective.
children.name: MBEDTLS_MEM_ALLOC_MODE
children.title: Memory allocation strategy

children.help:
Maximum TLS message length (in bytes) supported by mbedTLS.

16384 is the default and this value is required to comply
fully with TLS standards.

However you can set a lower value in order to save RAM. This
is safe if the other end of the connection supports Maximum
Fragment Length Negotiation Extension (max_fragment_length,
see RFC6066) or you know for certain that it will never send a
message longer than a certain number of bytes.

If the value is set too low, symptoms are a failed TLS
handshake or a return value of MBEDTLS_ERR_SSL_INVALID_RECORD
(-0x7200).
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_MAX_CONTENT_LEN
children.title: TLS maximum message content length

children.help:
This defines maximum incoming fragment length, overriding default
maximum content length (MBEDTLS_SSL_MAX_CONTENT_LEN).
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_IN_CONTENT_LEN
children.title: TLS maximum incoming fragment length

children.help:
This defines maximum outgoing fragment length, overriding default
maximum content length (MBEDTLS_SSL_MAX_CONTENT_LEN).
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_OUT_CONTENT_LEN
children.title: TLS maximum outgoing fragment length

children.help:
If enabled, this option allows customizing TLS in/out fragment length
in asymmetric way. Please note that enabling this with default values
saves 12KB of dynamic memory per TLS connection.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ASYMMETRIC_CONTENT_LEN
children.title: Asymmetric in/out fragment length

children.help: Free peer certificate after its usage in handshake process.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DYNAMIC_FREE_PEER_CERT
children.title: Free SSL peer certificate after its usage

children.help:
Free CA certificate after its usage in the handshake process.
This option will decrease the heap footprint for the TLS handshake, but may lead to a problem:
If the respective ssl object needs to perform the TLS handshake again,
the CA certificate should once again be registered to the ssl object.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DYNAMIC_FREE_CA_CERT
children.title: Free SSL CA certificate after its usage

children.help:
Free private key and DHM data after its usage in handshake process.

The option will decrease heap cost when handshake, but also lead to problem:

Becasue all certificate, private key and DHM data are freed so users should register
certificate and private key to ssl config object again.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DYNAMIC_FREE_CONFIG_DATA
children.title: Free private key and DHM data after its usage

children.help:
Using dynamic TX/RX buffer. After enabling this option, mbedTLS will
allocate TX buffer when need to send data and then free it if all data
is sent, allocate RX buffer when need to receive data and then free it
when all data is used or read by upper layer.

By default, when SSL is initialized, mbedTLS also allocate TX and
RX buffer with the default value of "MBEDTLS_SSL_OUT_CONTENT_LEN" or
"MBEDTLS_SSL_IN_CONTENT_LEN", so to save more heap, users can set
the options to be an appropriate value.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DYNAMIC_BUFFER
children.title: Using dynamic TX/RX buffer

children.help: Set mbedTLS debugging level
children.name: MBEDTLS_DEBUG_LEVEL
children.title: Set mbedTLS debugging level

children.help:
Enable mbedTLS debugging functions at compile time.

If this option is enabled, you can include
"mbedtls/esp_debug.h" and call mbedtls_esp_enable_debug_log()
at runtime in order to enable mbedTLS debug output via the ESP
log mechanism.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DEBUG
children.title: Enable mbedTLS debugging

children.name: MBEDTLS_CERTIFICATE_BUNDLE_DEFAULT_FULL
children.title: Use the full default certificate bundle

children.help:
Use only the most common certificates from the default bundles, reducing the size with 50%,
while still having around 99% coverage.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CERTIFICATE_BUNDLE_DEFAULT_CMN
children.title: Use only the most common certificates from the default bundles

children.name: MBEDTLS_CERTIFICATE_BUNDLE_DEFAULT_NONE
children.title: Do not use the default certificate bundle

children.help:
Name of the custom certificate directory or file. This path is evaluated
relative to the project root directory.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CUSTOM_CERTIFICATE_BUNDLE_PATH
children.title: Custom certificate bundle path

children.name: MBEDTLS_CUSTOM_CERTIFICATE_BUNDLE
children.title: Add custom certificates to the default bundle

children.help:
Enable support for large number of default root certificates

When enabled this option allows user to store default as well
as customer specific root certificates in compressed format rather
than storing full certificate. For the root certificates the public key and the subject name
will be stored.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CERTIFICATE_BUNDLE
children.title: Enable trusted root certificate bundle

children.help: Enable "non-blocking" ECC operations that can return early and be resumed.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_RESTARTABLE
children.title: Enable mbedTLS ecp restartable

children.help:
Enable the CMAC (Cipher-based Message Authentication Code) mode for
block ciphers.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CMAC_C
children.title: Enable CMAC mode for block ciphers

children.help:
Use an interrupt to coordinate long AES operations.

This allows other code to run on the CPU while an AES operation is pending.
Otherwise the CPU busy-waits.
children.name: MBEDTLS_AES_USE_INTERRUPT
children.title: Use interrupt for long AES operations

children.help:
Enable partially hardware accelerated GCM. GHASH calculation is still done
in software.

If MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_GCM is disabled and MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_AES is enabled then
mbedTLS will still use the hardware accelerated AES block operation, but
on a single block at a time.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_GCM
children.title: Enable partially hardware accelerated GCM

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated AES encryption & decryption.

Note that if the ESP32 CPU is running at 240MHz, hardware AES does not
offer any speed boost over software AES.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_AES
children.title: Enable hardware AES acceleration

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated multiple precision integer operations.

Hardware accelerated multiplication, modulo multiplication,
and modular exponentiation for up to SOC_RSA_MAX_BIT_LEN bit results.

These operations are used by RSA.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_MPI
children.title: Enable hardware MPI (bignum) acceleration

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated SHA1, SHA256, SHA384 & SHA512 in mbedTLS.

Due to a hardware limitation, on the ESP32 hardware acceleration is only
guaranteed if SHA digests are calculated one at a time. If more
than one SHA digest is calculated at the same time, one will
be calculated fully in hardware and the rest will be calculated
(at least partially calculated) in software. This happens automatically.

SHA hardware acceleration is faster than software in some situations but
slower in others. You should benchmark to find the best setting for you.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_SHA
children.title: Enable hardware SHA acceleration

children.help: Use ROM MD5 in mbedTLS.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ROM_MD5
children.title: Use MD5 implementation in ROM

children.help:
This option enables hardware acceleration for ECDSA sign function, only
when using ATECC608A cryptoauth chip (integrated with ESP32-WROOM-32SE)
children.name: MBEDTLS_ATCA_HW_ECDSA_SIGN
children.title: Enable hardware ECDSA sign acceleration when using ATECC608A

children.help:
This option enables hardware acceleration for ECDSA sign function, only
when using ATECC608A cryptoauth chip (integrated with ESP32-WROOM-32SE)
children.name: MBEDTLS_ATCA_HW_ECDSA_VERIFY
children.title: Enable hardware ECDSA verify acceleration when using ATECC608A

children.help:
Enables X.509 certificate expiry checks in mbedTLS.

If this option is disabled (default) then X.509 certificate
"valid from" and "valid to" timestamp fields are ignored.

If this option is enabled, these fields are compared with the
current system date and time. The time is retrieved using the
standard time() and gmtime() functions. If the certificate is not
valid for the current system time then verification will fail with
code MBEDTLS_X509_BADCERT_FUTURE or MBEDTLS_X509_BADCERT_EXPIRED.

Enabling this option requires adding functionality in the firmware
to set the system clock to a valid timestamp before using TLS. The
recommended way to do this is via ESP-IDF's SNTP functionality, but
any method can be used.

In the case where only a small number of certificates are trusted by
the device, please carefully consider the tradeoffs of enabling this
option. There may be undesired consequences, for example if all
trusted certificates expire while the device is offline and a TLS
connection is required to update. Or if an issue with the SNTP
server means that the system time is invalid for an extended period
after a reset.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HAVE_TIME_DATE
children.title: Enable mbedtls certificate expiry check

children.help:
Enable use of time.h functions (time() and gmtime()) by mbedTLS.

This option doesn't require the system time to be correct, but enables
functionality that requires relative timekeeping - for example periodic
expiry of TLS session tickets or session cache entries.

Disabling this option will save some firmware size, particularly if
the rest of the firmware doesn't call any standard timekeeeping
functions.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HAVE_TIME
children.title: Enable mbedtls time support

children.help:
Standard ECDSA is "fragile" in the sense that lack of entropy when signing
may result in a compromise of the long-term signing key.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECDSA_DETERMINISTIC
children.title: Enable deterministic ECDSA

children.help: Enable MBEDTLS_SHA512_C adds support for SHA-384 and SHA-512.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SHA512_C
children.title: Enable the SHA-384 and SHA-512 cryptographic hash algorithms

children.help:
mbedTLS can be compiled with protocol support for the TLS
server, TLS client, or both server and client.

Reducing the number of TLS roles supported saves code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_TLS_MODE
children.title: TLS Protocol Role

children.help: Enable to support symmetric key PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS key exchange modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_PSK
children.title: Enable PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support Diffie-Hellman PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_DHE_PSK
children.title: Enable DHE-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support Elliptic-Curve-Diffie-Hellman PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_PSK
children.title: Enable ECDHE-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support RSA PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_RSA_PSK
children.title: Enable RSA-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help:
Enable to show configuration for different types of pre-shared-key TLS authentatication methods.

Leaving this options disabled will save code size if they are not used.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PSK_MODES
children.title: Enable pre-shared-key ciphersuites

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_RSA
children.title: Enable RSA-only based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-DHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_DHE_RSA
children.title: Enable DHE-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_RSA
children.title: Enable ECDHE-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_ECDSA
children.title: Enable ECDHE-ECDSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDH_ECDSA
children.title: Enable ECDH-ECDSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDH_RSA
children.title: Enable ECDH-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help:
Enable to show Elliptic Curve based ciphersuite mode options.

Disabling all Elliptic Curve ciphersuites saves code size and
can give slightly faster TLS handshakes, provided the server supports
RSA-only ciphersuite modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ELLIPTIC_CURVE
children.title: Support Elliptic Curve based ciphersuites

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECJPAKE-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECJPAKE
children.title: Enable ECJPAKE based ciphersuite modes

children.help:
The two main uses of renegotiation are (1) refresh keys on long-lived
connections and (2) client authentication after the initial handshake.
If you don't need renegotiation, disabling it will save code size and
reduce the possibility of abuse/vulnerability.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_RENEGOTIATION
children.title: Support TLS renegotiation

children.help:
Support the legacy SSL 3.0 protocol. Most servers will speak a newer
TLS protocol these days.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_PROTO_SSL3
children.title: Legacy SSL 3.0 support

children.help: Provisions for GM/T SSL 1.1 support
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_PROTO_GMTSSL1_1
children.title: Support GM/T SSL 1.1 protocol

children.help:
Requires TLS 1.1 to be enabled for DTLS 1.0
Requires TLS 1.2 to be enabled for DTLS 1.2
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_PROTO_DTLS
children.title: Support DTLS protocol (all versions)

children.help: Disabling this option will save some code size if it is not needed.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_ALPN
children.title: Support ALPN (Application Layer Protocol Negotiation)

children.help:
Client support for RFC 5077 session tickets. See mbedTLS documentation for more details.
Disabling this option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CLIENT_SSL_SESSION_TICKETS
children.title: TLS: Client Support for RFC 5077 SSL session tickets

children.help:
Disabling this avoids problems with mis-issued and/or misused (intermediate) CA and leaf certificates.
Depending on your PKI use, disabling this can be a security risk.
children.name: MBEDTLS_X509_CHECK_KEY_USAGE
children.title: Enable verification of the keyUsage extension

children.help:
Disabling this avoids problems with mis-issued and/or misused certificates.
Depending on your PKI use, disabling this can be a security risk.
children.name: MBEDTLS_X509_CHECK_EXTENDED_KEY_USAGE
children.title: Enable verification of the extendedKeyUsage extension

children.help:
Server support for RFC 5077 session tickets. See mbedTLS documentation for more details.
Disabling this option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SERVER_SSL_SESSION_TICKETS
children.title: TLS: Server Support for RFC 5077 SSL session tickets

children.help:
Enables the DES block cipher to support 3DES-based TLS ciphersuites.

3DES is vulnerable to the Sweet32 attack and should only be enabled
if absolutely necessary.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DES_C
children.title: DES block cipher (legacy, insecure)

children.help:
ARCFOUR (RC4) stream cipher can be disabled entirely, enabled but not
added to default ciphersuites, or enabled completely.

Please consider the security implications before enabling RC4.
children.name: MBEDTLS_RC4_MODE
children.title: RC4 Stream Cipher (legacy, insecure)

children.help:
Enables the Blowfish block cipher (not used for TLS sessions.)

The Blowfish cipher is not used for mbedTLS TLS sessions but can be
used for other purposes. Read up on the limitations of Blowfish (including
Sweet32) before enabling.
children.name: MBEDTLS_BLOWFISH_C
children.title: Blowfish block cipher (read help)

children.help: Enables the XTEA block cipher.
children.name: MBEDTLS_XTEA_C
children.title: XTEA block cipher

children.help:
Enable Counter with CBC-MAC (CCM) modes for AES and/or Camellia ciphers.

Disabling this option saves some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CCM_C
children.title: CCM (Counter with CBC-MAC) block cipher modes

children.help:
Enable Galois/Counter Mode for AES and/or Camellia ciphers.

This option is generally faster than CCM.
children.name: MBEDTLS_GCM_C
children.title: GCM (Galois/Counter) block cipher modes

children.help: Enable NIST key wrapping and key wrapping padding.
children.name: MBEDTLS_NIST_KW_C
children.title: NIST key wrapping (KW) and KW padding (KWP)

children.help: Enable the RIPEMD-160 hash algorithm.
children.name: MBEDTLS_RIPEMD160_C
children.title: Enable RIPEMD-160 hash algorithm

children.help:
Enable decoding/parsing of PEM formatted certificates.

If your certificates are all in the simpler DER format, disabling
this option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PEM_PARSE_C
children.title: Read & Parse PEM formatted certificates

children.help:
Enable writing of PEM formatted certificates.

If writing certificate data only in DER format, disabling this
option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PEM_WRITE_C
children.title: Write PEM formatted certificates

children.help: Support for parsing X.509 Certifificate Revocation Lists.
children.name: MBEDTLS_X509_CRL_PARSE_C
children.title: X.509 CRL parsing

children.help: Support for parsing X.509 Certifificate Signing Requests
children.name: MBEDTLS_X509_CSR_PARSE_C
children.title: X.509 CSR parsing

children.help: Enable ECDSA. Needed to use ECDSA-xxx TLS ciphersuites.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECDSA_C
children.title: Elliptic Curve DSA

children.help: Enable ECDH. Needed to use ECDHE-xxx TLS ciphersuites.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECDH_C
children.title: Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH)

children.help: Enable ECJPAKE. Needed to use ECJPAKE-xxx TLS ciphersuites.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECJPAKE_C
children.title: Elliptic curve J-PAKE

children.help: Enable support for SECP192R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP192R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP192R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP224R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP224R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP224R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP256R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP256R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP256R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP384R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP384R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP384R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP521R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP521R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP521R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP192K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP192K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP192K1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP224K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP224K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP224K1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP256K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP256K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP256K1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP256R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP256R1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP384R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP384R1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP512R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP512R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for CURVE25519 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_CURVE25519_ENABLED
children.title: Enable CURVE25519 curve

children.help:
NIST 'modulo p' optimisations increase Elliptic Curve operation performance.

Disabling this option saves some code size.

# end of Elliptic Curve options
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_NIST_OPTIM
children.title: NIST 'modulo p' optimisations

children.help: Enable support for Poly1305 MAC algorithm.
children.name: MBEDTLS_POLY1305_C
children.title: Poly1305 MAC algorithm

children.help: Enable support for ChaCha20-Poly1305 AEAD algorithm.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CHACHAPOLY_C
children.title: ChaCha20-Poly1305 AEAD algorithm

children.help: Enable support for Chacha20 stream cipher.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CHACHA20_C
children.title: Chacha20 stream cipher

children.help:
Enable support for the Hashed Message Authentication Code
(HMAC)-based key derivation function (HKDF).
children.name: MBEDTLS_HKDF_C
children.title: HKDF algorithm (RFC 5869)

children.help: Enable threading alt to allow your own alternate threading implementation.
children.name: MBEDTLS_THREADING_ALT
children.title: Enable threading alternate implementation

children.help: Enable the pthread wrapper layer for the threading layer.
children.name: MBEDTLS_THREADING_PTHREAD
children.title: Enable threading pthread implementation

children.help:
If you do intend to use contexts between threads, you will need to enable
this layer to prevent race conditions.
children.name: MBEDTLS_THREADING_C
children.title: Enable the threading abstraction layer

children.help:
Fallback to software implementation for RSA key lengths
larger than SOC_RSA_MAX_BIT_LEN. If this is not active
then the ESP will be unable to process keys greater
than SOC_RSA_MAX_BIT_LEN.
children.name: MBEDTLS_LARGE_KEY_SOFTWARE_MPI
children.title: Fallback to software implementation for larger MPI values

children.help:
Allow the X.509 certificate parser to load certificates
with unsupported critical extensions
children.name: MBEDTLS_ALLOW_UNSUPPORTED_CRITICAL_EXT
children.title: X.509 CRT parsing with unsupported critical extensions

children.name: MBEDTLS_SECURITY_RISKS
children.title: Show configurations with potential security risks

children.help:
Services take up a certain amount of memory, and allowing fewer
services to be open at the same time conserves memory. Specify
the maximum amount of services here. The valid value is from 1
to 64.
children.name: MDNS_MAX_SERVICES
children.title: Max number of services

children.help:
Allows setting mDNS task priority. Please do not set the task priority
higher than priorities of system tasks. Compile time warning/error
would be emitted if the chosen task priority were too high.
children.name: MDNS_TASK_PRIORITY
children.title: mDNS task priority

children.help: Allows setting mDNS task stacksize.
children.name: MDNS_TASK_STACK_SIZE
children.title: mDNS task stack size

children.help:
Allows setting mDNS tasks affinity, i.e. whether the task is pinned to
CPU0, pinned to CPU1, or allowed to run on any CPU.
children.name: MDNS_TASK_AFFINITY
children.title: mDNS task affinity

children.help:
Configures timeout for adding a new mDNS service. Adding a service
fails if could not be completed within this time.
children.name: MDNS_SERVICE_ADD_TIMEOUT_MS
children.title: mDNS adding service timeout (ms)

children.help:
Configures strict mode. Set this to 1 for the mDNS library to strictly follow the RFC6762:
Currently the only strict feature: Do not repeat original questions in response packets
(defined in RFC6762 sec. 6).
Default configuration is 0, i.e. non-strict mode, since some implementations,
such as lwIP mdns resolver (used by standard POSIX API like getaddrinfo, gethostbyname)
could not correctly resolve advertised names.
children.name: MDNS_STRICT_MODE
children.title: mDNS strict mode

children.help:
Configures period of mDNS timer, which periodically transmits packets
and schedules mDNS searches.
children.name: MDNS_TIMER_PERIOD_MS
children.title: mDNS timer period (ms)

children.help:
Enables optional mdns networking implementation using BSD sockets
in UDP multicast mode.
This option creates a new thread to serve receiving packets (TODO).
This option uses additional N sockets, where N is number of interfaces.
children.name: MDNS_NETWORKING_SOCKET
children.title: Use BSD sockets for mdns networking

children.help: Enables adding multiple service instances under the same service type.
children.name: MDNS_MULTIPLE_INSTANCE
children.title: Multiple instances under the same service type

children.help: If not, this library will use MQTT protocol 3.1
children.name: MQTT_PROTOCOL_311
children.title: Enable MQTT protocol 3.1.1

children.help: Enable MQTT transport over SSL with mbedtls
children.name: MQTT_TRANSPORT_SSL
children.title: Enable MQTT over SSL

children.help: Enable MQTT transport over Websocket Secure.
children.name: MQTT_TRANSPORT_WEBSOCKET_SECURE
children.title: Enable MQTT over Websocket Secure

children.help: Enable MQTT transport over Websocket.
children.name: MQTT_TRANSPORT_WEBSOCKET
children.title: Enable MQTT over Websocket

children.help:
Set this to true for the message id (2.3.1 Packet Identifier) to be generated
as an incremental number rather then a random value (used by default)
children.name: MQTT_MSG_ID_INCREMENTAL
children.title: Use Incremental Message Id

children.help:
Set this to true to avoid publishing (enqueueing messages) if the client is disconnected.
The MQTT client tries to publish all messages by default, even in the disconnected state
(where the qos1 and qos2 packets are stored in the internal outbox to be published later)
The MQTT_SKIP_PUBLISH_IF_DISCONNECTED option allows applications to override this behaviour
and not enqueue publish packets in the disconnected state.
children.name: MQTT_SKIP_PUBLISH_IF_DISCONNECTED
children.title: Skip publish if disconnected

children.help:
Set this to true to post events for all messages which were deleted from the outbox
before being correctly sent and confirmed.
children.name: MQTT_REPORT_DELETED_MESSAGES
children.title: Report deleted messages

children.help: Default MQTT over TCP port
children.name: MQTT_TCP_DEFAULT_PORT
children.title: Default MQTT over TCP port

children.help: Default MQTT over SSL port
children.name: MQTT_SSL_DEFAULT_PORT
children.title: Default MQTT over SSL port

children.help: Default MQTT over Websocket port
children.name: MQTT_WS_DEFAULT_PORT
children.title: Default MQTT over Websocket port

children.help: Default MQTT over Websocket Secure port
children.name: MQTT_WSS_DEFAULT_PORT
children.title: Default MQTT over Websocket Secure port

children.help: This buffer size using for both transmit and receive
children.name: MQTT_BUFFER_SIZE
children.title: Default MQTT Buffer Size

children.help: MQTT task stack size
children.name: MQTT_TASK_STACK_SIZE
children.title: MQTT task stack size

children.help:
Default config employs API locks to protect internal structures. It is possible to disable
these locks if the user code doesn't access MQTT API from multiple concurrent tasks
children.name: MQTT_DISABLE_API_LOCKS
children.title: Disable API locks

children.help: MQTT task priority. Higher number denotes higher priority.
children.name: MQTT_TASK_PRIORITY
children.title: MQTT task priority

children.help: Custom MQTT configurations.
children.name: MQTT_USE_CUSTOM_CONFIG
children.title: MQTT Using custom configurations

children.help: This will enable core selection
children.name: MQTT_TASK_CORE_SELECTION_ENABLED
children.title: Enable MQTT task core selection

children.help:
Set to true if a specific implementation of message outbox is needed (e.g. persistant outbox in NVM or
similar).
children.name: MQTT_CUSTOM_OUTBOX
children.title: Enable custom outbox implementation

children.help: Messages which stays in the outbox longer than this value before being published will be discarded.
children.name: MQTT_OUTBOX_EXPIRED_TIMEOUT_MS
children.title: Outbox message expired timeout[ms]

children.help:
This option allows configuring the desired line endings sent to UART
when a newline ('\n', LF) appears on stdout.
Three options are possible:

CRLF: whenever LF is encountered, prepend it with CR

LF: no modification is applied, stdout is sent as is

CR: each occurence of LF is replaced with CR

This option doesn't affect behavior of the UART driver (drivers/uart.h).
children.name: NEWLIB_STDOUT_LINE_ENDING
children.title: Line ending for UART output

children.help:
This option allows configuring which input sequence on UART produces
a newline ('\n', LF) on stdin.
Three options are possible:

CRLF: CRLF is converted to LF

LF: no modification is applied, input is sent to stdin as is

CR: each occurence of CR is replaced with LF

This option doesn't affect behavior of the UART driver (drivers/uart.h).
children.name: NEWLIB_STDIN_LINE_ENDING
children.title: Line ending for UART input

children.help:
ESP32 ROM contains parts of newlib C library, including printf/scanf family
of functions. These functions have been compiled with so-called "nano"
formatting option. This option doesn't support 64-bit integer formats and C99
features, such as positional arguments.

For more details about "nano" formatting option, please see newlib readme file,
search for '--enable-newlib-nano-formatted-io':
https://sourceware.org/newlib/README

If this option is enabled, build system will use functions available in
ROM, reducing the application binary size. Functions available in ROM run
faster than functions which run from flash. Functions available in ROM can
also run when flash instruction cache is disabled.

If you need 64-bit integer formatting support or C99 features, keep this
option disabled.
children.name: NEWLIB_NANO_FORMAT
children.title: Enable 'nano' formatting options for printf/scanf family

children.help:
This option enables encryption for NVS. When enabled, AES-XTS is used to encrypt
the complete NVS data, except the page headers. It requires XTS encryption keys
to be stored in an encrypted partition. This means enabling flash encryption is
a pre-requisite for this feature.
children.name: NVS_ENCRYPTION
children.title: Enable NVS encryption

children.help:
Enabling this will ignore "encrypted" flag for NVS partitions. NVS encryption
scheme is different than hardware flash encryption and hence it is not recommended
to have "encrypted" flag for NVS partitions. This was not being checked in pre v4.3
IDF. Hence, if you have any devices where this flag is kept enabled in partition
table then enabling this config will allow to have same behavior as pre v4.3 IDF.
children.name: NVS_COMPATIBLE_PRE_V4_3_ENCRYPTION_FLAG
children.title: NVS partition encrypted flag compatible with ESP-IDF before v4.3

children.help:
Enable OpenSSL debugging function.

If the option is enabled, "SSL_DEBUG" works.
children.name: OPENSSL_DEBUG
children.title: Enable OpenSSL debugging

children.help: Enable OpenSSL Error reporting
children.name: OPENSSL_ERROR_STACK
children.title: Enable OpenSSL error structure

children.help:
OpenSSL debugging level.

Only function whose debugging level is higher than "OPENSSL_DEBUG_LEVEL" works.

For example:
If OPENSSL_DEBUG_LEVEL = 2, you use function "SSL_DEBUG(1, "malloc failed")". Because 1 < 2, it will not
print.
children.name: OPENSSL_DEBUG_LEVEL
children.title: OpenSSL debugging level

children.help:
If the option is enabled, low-level module debugging function of OpenSSL is enabled, e.g. mbedtls internal
debugging function.
children.name: OPENSSL_LOWLEVEL_DEBUG
children.title: Enable OpenSSL low-level module debugging

children.help: Do nothing and "SSL_ASSERT" does not work.
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT_DO_NOTHING
children.title: Do nothing

children.help: Enable assert exiting, it will check and return error code.
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT_EXIT
children.title: Check and exit

children.help: Enable assert debugging, it will check and show debugging message.
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT_DEBUG
children.title: Show debugging message

children.help: Enable assert debugging and exiting, it will check, show debugging message and return error code.
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT_DEBUG_EXIT
children.title: Show debugging message and exit

children.help: Enable assert debugging and blocking, it will check, show debugging message and block by "while (1);".
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT_DEBUG_BLOCK
children.title: Show debugging message and block

children.help:
OpenSSL function needs "assert" function to check if input parameters are valid.

If you want to use assert debugging function, "OPENSSL_DEBUG" should be enabled.
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT
children.title: Select OpenSSL assert function

children.help: Select this to use the native 15.4 radio.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_RADIO_NATIVE
children.title: Native 15.4 radio

children.help: Select this to connect to a Radio Co-Processor via UART.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_RADIO_SPINEL_UART
children.title: Connect via UART

children.help: Configure how OpenThread connects to the 15.4 radio
children.name: OPENTHREAD_RADIO_TYPE
children.title: Config the Thread radio type

children.help: Select this to enable Full Thread Device which can act as router and leader in a Thread network.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_FTD
children.title: Full Thread Device

children.help:
Select this to enable Minimal Thread Device which can only act as end device in a Thread network.
This will reduce the code size of the OpenThread stack.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_MTD
children.title: Minimal Thread Device

children.help:
Select this to enable Radio Only Device which cannot can only forward 15.4 packets to the host.
The OpenThread stack will be run on the host and OpenThread will have minimal footprint on the
radio only device.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_RADIO
children.title: Radio Only Device

children.help: OpenThread can be configured to different device types (FTD, MTD, Radio)
children.name: OPENTHREAD_DEVICE_TYPE
children.title: Config the Thread device type

children.help:
Select this option to enable Diag in OpenThread. This will enable diag mode and a series of diag commands
in the OpenThread command line. These commands allow users to manipulate low-level features of the storage
and 15.4 radio.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_DIAG
children.title: Enable diag

children.help:
Select this option to enable commissioner in OpenThread. This will enable the device to act as a
commissioner in the Thread network. A commissioner checks the pre-shared key from a joining device with
the Thread commissioning protocol and shares the network parameter with the joining device upon success.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_COMMISSIONER
children.title: Enable Commissioner

children.help:
Select this option to enable Joiner in OpenThread. This allows a device to join the Thread network with a
pre-shared key using the Thread commissioning protocol.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_JOINER
children.title: Enable Joiner

children.help:
Select this option to enable SRP Client in OpenThread. This allows a device to register SRP services to SRP
Server.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_SRP_CLIENT
children.title: Enable SRP Client

children.help: Select this option to enable border router features in OpenThread.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_BORDER_ROUTER
children.title: Enable Border Router

children.help: Override the shipped libopenthread_br.a and libopenthread_port.a, for internal builds.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_ESP_LIB_FROM_INTERNAL_SRC
children.title: Build esp_openthread libraries from source

children.name: OPENTHREAD_NUM_MESSAGE_BUFFERS
children.title: The number of openthread message buffers

children.help: Select this option to enable OpenThread and show the submenu with OpenThread configuration choices.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_ENABLED
children.title: OpenThread

children.help: Priority used to create new tasks with default pthread parameters.
children.name: PTHREAD_TASK_PRIO_DEFAULT
children.title: Default task priority

children.help: Stack size used to create new tasks with default pthread parameters.
children.name: PTHREAD_TASK_STACK_SIZE_DEFAULT
children.title: Default task stack size

children.help: Minimum allowed pthread stack size set in attributes passed to pthread_create
children.name: PTHREAD_STACK_MIN
children.title: Minimum allowed pthread stack size

children.help: The default core to which pthreads are pinned.
children.name: PTHREAD_TASK_CORE_DEFAULT
children.title: Default pthread core affinity

children.help: The default name of pthreads.
children.name: PTHREAD_TASK_NAME_DEFAULT
children.title: Default name of pthreads

children.help:
If this option is enabled, if SPI flash write verification fails then a log error line
will be written with the address, expected & actual values. This can be useful when
debugging hardware SPI flash problems.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_LOG_FAILED_WRITE
children.title: Log errors if verification fails

children.help:
If this option is enabled, any SPI flash write which tries to set zero bits in the flash to
ones will log a warning. Such writes will not result in the requested data appearing identically
in flash once written, as SPI NOR flash can only set bits to one when an entire sector is erased.
After erasing, individual bits can only be written from one to zero.

Note that some software (such as SPIFFS) which is aware of SPI NOR flash may write one bits as an
optimisation, relying on the data in flash becoming a bitwise AND of the new data and any existing data.
Such software will log spurious warnings if this option is enabled.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_WARN_SETTING_ZERO_TO_ONE
children.title: Log warning if writing zero bits to ones

children.help:
If this option is enabled, any time SPI flash is written then the data will be read
back and verified. This can catch hardware problems with SPI flash, or flash which
was not erased before verification.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_VERIFY_WRITE
children.title: Verify SPI flash writes

children.help:
This option enables the following APIs:

- spi_flash_reset_counters
- spi_flash_dump_counters
- spi_flash_get_counters

These APIs may be used to collect performance data for spi_flash APIs
and to help understand behaviour of libraries which use SPI flash.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ENABLE_COUNTERS
children.title: Enable operation counters

children.help:
Enable this flag to use patched versions of SPI flash ROM driver functions.
This option should be enabled, if any one of the following is true: (1) need to write
to flash on ESP32-D2WD; (2) main SPI flash is connected to non-default pins; (3) main
SPI flash chip is manufactured by ISSI.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ROM_DRIVER_PATCH
children.title: Enable SPI flash ROM driver patched functions

children.help:
Enable this flag to use new SPI flash driver functions from ROM instead of ESP-IDF.

If keeping this as "n" in your project, you will have less free IRAM.
But you can use all of our flash features.

If making this as "y" in your project, you will increase free IRAM.
But you may miss out on some flash features and support for new flash chips.

Currently the ROM cannot support the following features:

- SPI_FLASH_AUTO_SUSPEND (C3, S3)
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ROM_IMPL
children.title: Use esp_flash implementation in ROM

children.help:
SPI flash APIs can optionally abort or return a failure code
if erasing or writing addresses that fall at the beginning
of flash (covering the bootloader and partition table) or that
overlap the app partition that contains the running app.

It is not recommended to ever write to these regions from an IDF app,
and this check prevents logic errors or corrupted firmware memory from
damaging these regions.

Note that this feature *does not* check calls to the esp_rom_xxx SPI flash
ROM functions. These functions should not be called directly from IDF
applications.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_DANGEROUS_WRITE
children.title: Writing to dangerous flash regions

children.help:
The implementation of SPI flash has been greatly changed in IDF v4.0.
Enable this option to use the legacy implementation.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_USE_LEGACY_IMPL
children.title: Use the legacy implementation before IDF v4.0

children.help:
Each SPI bus needs a lock for arbitration among devices. This allows multiple
devices on a same bus, but may reduce the speed of esp_flash driver access to the
main flash chip.

If you only need to use esp_flash driver to access the main flash chip, disable
this option, and the lock will be bypassed on SPI1 bus. Otherwise if extra devices
are needed to attach to SPI1 bus, enable this option.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SHARE_SPI1_BUS
children.title: Support other devices attached to SPI1 bus

children.help:
Some flash chips can have very high "max" erase times, especially for block erase (32KB or 64KB).
This option allows to bypass "block erase" and always do sector erase commands.
This will be much slower overall in most cases, but improves latency for other code to run.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_BYPASS_BLOCK_ERASE
children.title: Bypass a block erase and always do sector erase

children.help:
If a duration of one erase command is large
then it will yield CPUs after finishing a current command.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ERASE_YIELD_DURATION_MS
children.title: Duration of erasing to yield CPUs (ms)

children.help: Defines how many ticks will be before returning to continue a erasing.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ERASE_YIELD_TICKS
children.title: CPU release time (tick) for an erase operation

children.help:
This allows to yield the CPUs between erase commands.
Prevents starvation of other tasks.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_YIELD_DURING_ERASE
children.title: Enables yield operation during flash erase

children.help:
This option is default n before ESP32-C3, because it needs bootloader support.

CAUTION: If you want to OTA to an app with this feature turned on, please make
sure the bootloader has the support for it. (later than IDF v4.3)

Auto-suspend feature only supported by XMC chip.
If you are using an official module, please contact Espressif Business support.
Also reading auto suspend part in `SPI Flash API` document before you enable this function.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_AUTO_SUSPEND
children.title: Auto suspend long erase/write operations (READ DOCS FIRST)

children.help:
Flash write is broken down in terms of multiple (smaller) write operations.
This configuration options helps to set individual write chunk size, smaller
value here ensures that cache (and non-IRAM resident interrupts) remains
disabled for shorter duration.
